enrich_metadata.label: Dana Point, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Dana Point, Orange County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Dana Point is a city located in southern Orange County, California. The population was 33,351 at the 2010 census. It has one of the few harbors along the Orange County coast, and with ready access via State Route 1, it is a popular local destination for surfing. The city was named after the headland of Dana Point, which was in turn named after Richard Henry Dana, Jr., author of Two Years Before the Mast, which included a description of the area. Dana described the locale, including neighboring San Juan Capistrano, as "the only romantic spot on the coast". Although Dana described the anchorage as poor, it is now a developed harbor and contains a replica of his ship, the Pilgrim. The Pilgrim is used as a classroom by the Ocean Institute, which is located at the harbor. This area is designated California Historical Landmark #189.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Dana_Point,_California

enrich_metadata.mention_address: San Juan Capistrano, Orange County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Juan Capistrano (/sæn ˌwɑːn kæpᵻˈstrɑːnoʊ/; [saŋ ˈxwaŋ kapisˈtɾano]) is a city in Orange County, California, United States. The current OMB metropolitan designation for San Juan Capistrano and the Orange County Area is "Santa Ana-Anaheim-Irvine, CA." The population was 34,593 at the 2010 census, up from 33,826 at the 2000 census. The city was created around Mission San Juan Capistrano, and many of the homes and strip malls resemble the Spanish architecture that composes the building. It is home to the widest variety of homes in Orange County, including those built prior to 1900 in its central district (some being adobes from the 18th century). San Juan Capistrano formerly hosted a population of cliff swallows that migrate each year from Argentina to the Mission San Juan Capistrano.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/San_Juan_Capistrano,_California

The current OMB metropolitan designation for San Juan Capistrano and the Orange County Area is "Santa Ana-Anaheim-Irvine, CA." The population was 34,593 at the 2010 census, up from 33,826 at the 2000 census. The city was created around Mission San Juan Capistrano, and many of the homes and strip malls resemble the Spanish architecture that composes the building. It is home to the widest variety of homes in Orange County, including those built prior to 1900 in its central district (some being adobes from the 18th century). San Juan Capistrano formerly hosted a population of cliff swallows that migrate each year from Argentina to the Mission San Juan Capistrano.

san fernando valley.address: San Fernando, Los Angeles County, California, United States of America

attraction_reviewComments: This area is for youngster and hipster. Party on weekend is crazy...time to time I see people get thrown out because they were so drunk!! ... but its all good fun.
(Although the folks in Del Mar will argue about this.) Best food, best good times, best and most affordable/clean places to stay, best nightlife.
I love California beaches. I like this beach for the diversity of the people, the historic pier, the sand quality, ease of parking, and proximity to restaurants and businesses... read more
PB is known for it's nightlife. But it is also a very diverse community with families and couples. Ton's to do - surfing, walking, biking. Many interesting restaurants and... read more
We stayed at a great hotel on the beach. Very convenient location to everywhere in San Diego who want to go
We went for an early morning walk. It was the weekend and we were glad we got up early. Parking would have been an issue. The water is chilly for us Texans. But we loved the... read more
Pacific Beach is a great "beachy" area in San Diego. It is big enough where you have tons of restaurants, bars, stores, services etc.. and the beaches are big and very enjoyable... read more
Pacific Beach is just north of Mission Beach, and the beaches themselves are very similar. The biggest differences is really the people, the parking, and the surrounding shops... read more
Lots of young people and energy on this beach. No smoking and drinking on the beach itself, so that may be a plus or downside for some of us. North of the crystal pier is where... read more
Always a great beach to walk and enjoy the Pacific.
The beach is beautiful, clean, nice place to visit, has big waves, great for surfing and swimming, has nice places to eat along the beach.
Very nice beach, and relatively uncrowded for Comic Con weekend. Really clean and pretty.
More of your "public beach" feel with a wide mix of patrons. This is your surfer beach and a great place to watch people catch waves. Very nice in the late afternoon.
Great for surf/sun/sand, the beach and town are all for fun. Definitely for the college kids and young adults, this place can be alittle hectic, tons of shops, food, and fun... read more
Maybe a bit crowded for the older folks, but endless fun and things to do. Walk across the street to the bay, take surfing lessons, go sailing, great food and best of all watch... read more
We staying in Pacific Beach & there was so much to do & see. Just walking up & down the beach was great fun but the shops & restaurants were very plentiful!
I love this place were staying in a condo right on the beach, surf was great I took my first lesson with Ryan from PB surf school absolutely amazing place people are drunk and... read more
Beach access (like almost every public beach) is a little tricky, but we found public parking for $5 per hour one block away. The beach was free of any visible trash, plenty of... read more
I spent an afternoon at PB after a business trip presented me with unexpected free time. I spent about 3 hours reading on the beach and walking up and down the boardwalk. Even in... read more
smallish beach, but perfect. Waves were good enough for plenty of surfers (in March), yet gentle enough for wading/swimming. Excellent sand quality, perfect for beach volleyball... read more
Cool beach where you will see lots of surfers as well as people just hanging on the sand. Tons of bars, restaurants and shopping across the street from the beach! Best part- there... read more
Our stay was great! We walked, walked some more, and even more. The beach is clean, a lot of seaweed washed up on the shore, but plenty of space to walk around it. We walked to... read more
Stayed at 725 Jamaica Ct. Had a great time. Had a view of the ocean from second floor. Very close to the boardwalk and beach. Would recommend to all my friends. We were there five... read more
This is a nice beach, seemed to have fewer children running around and more sunbathers. Nice to catch some rays and take in the view/sounds of the ocean without the screaming of... read more
We had started out trying to go to mission beach and Belmont park, but it was crazy crowded and we could find NO parking. So we kept going until we got to pacific beach, and I'm... read more
So, I truely know the best about PB as us locals call it, I live here. Most people crowd down south in Mission Beach towards the roller coaster. But the farther north you go... read more
This is a southern California beach of the imagination, at least of my imagination. Surfers and boogie boarders in the ocean, people fishing off the pier, joggers... read more
I love PB- great food and entertainment . But most of all the views of the ocean and the bay are top notch. The only draw back is the traffic - but it is worth it !
These San Diego beaches are some of the cleanest and friendliest beaches ever. Fantastic walk and plenty of fresh food vendors to stop for a snack or a craft beer.
Nice beach area, seems popular with the surfers, as there were quite a few. The weather was nice (still not used to this 75 in January), so quite a few people were out, doing... read more
We had breakfast at Kona on the corner. We sat on the patio and enjoyed the marvelous views. We were lucky to see a couple dolfins. We took a walk around the area and down to the... read more
Pacific Beach is not high end like La Jolla but has real California beach community charm. There is a long boardwalk along the beach with bars and restaurants. There are also many... read more
We stopped here on a Saturday and WOW it was crazy. We had a hard time finding a parking spot (about 3 blocks away on street parking). The beach is beautiful, wide, surfers... read more
Our family loved staying at Pacific Beach/Mission Bay. The area is lovely, fun, interesting and of course beautiful. Location is convenient to many great places to eat, sights and... read more
We stayed in a condo one block from the beach for 5 nights and 6 days and it was a blast! If you get the chance, visit the restaurant Firehouse, attached to an actual firehouse... read more
we loved the feel of this area. Very relaxed and unsophisticated. It was spring break and was full of young people hanging around, at the beach, surfing and having beers on the... read more
Being from Ny, this was my first time being to a beach with the Pacific Ocean. This beach is beautiful. Great scenery, eye candy and plenty of great shops. Do go, walk the ocean... read more
We really enjoyed walking along Pacific Beach watching the joggers and more serious runners as well as the surfers. The waves were awesome and watching these surfers challenge... read more
Spent month of March exploring this area from our comfortable condo at Capri by the Sea. We are older than most people here but loved walking the strand every day and watching... read more
We were in San Diego for thanksgiving. We got lucky and the weather was beautiful. The beach not crowded at all compared to the summer. The water was even still warm enough for... read more
Lovely beach, not to crowded even in the summer, Great playe to surf for beginners, nice restaurants close by. You can often spot dolphins playing just of shore!
Busy on the weekends, but what beach isn't? The water is amazing and there were plenty of parking available in the area for a price.
It wasn't even summer when I got here but the sun was shining every day and it was perfect beach weather every day.
The best family friendly surfing beach in San Diego . It's very clean with a laid back atmosphere. Our favorite beach.
Beautiful views of the Pacific Ocean and walks with lots of sights to see.Take time to enjoy the ocean and surfers.
Big, wide beach. Make sure you don't try to swim in the surfing section. Beach and water were clean and there is plenty of room so you don't feel crowded.
It's a nice beach, with great restaurants and bar. A lot of young and beautiful people, sports bar are everywhere. And the sunset from there is gorgeous.
Pacific beach is one of the beaches on the San Diego bay stretch and is popular with families for its low tide and smooth sand. One can start or terminate their bay walk at this... read more
Wonderful area of San Diego with nice shops and restrurants. Readily available grocery and drug stores. Clean and friendly. Watch out for summer afternoon traffic leaving... read more
Bring your hiking shoes..Amazing views, cliffs steep beachfront walks..Lovely shops and a neat little local village feel just 4 miles fom bustling San Diego..Parking free is a... read more
Pacific beach is a typical California beach community. The main area has bars, restaurants and of course surf shops. I tend to goo too the northern part of the beach where most of... read more
Great location. Accessible via public transportation. Bathhouse and outdoor showers. Lifeguard station. Restaurants/bars very close.
Pacific Beach is the middle class version of La Jolla. There are some cute bungalows and a tone of places to eat. The beach is also amazing. Wear good shoes so that you can walk... read more
We love this place. We go once a year to San Diego to see the granddaughter and usually stay in the PB area. The restaurants are great and the atmosphere is wonderful. The path... read more
Pacific beach is a great place to beach, but also a great place to stay. Once you get here, you rarely need to use your car, because everything is within walking distance! Aside... read more
Great location. Food, hotel, shopping. We loved for our Xmas visit. Central to going wherever you want & traffic wasn't too bad.
Pacific and Mission Beach are beautiful areas in San Diego. Beautiful views. Great surfing. Affordable. If you want 5 star restaurants and spas--you do not want this--go... read more

enrich_metadata.label: San Diego
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Diego /ˌsæn diːˈeɪɡoʊ/ (Spanish for "Saint Didacus") is a major city in California, on the coast of the Pacific Ocean in Southern California, approximately 120 miles (190 km) south of Los Angeles and immediately adjacent to the border with Mexico. With an estimated population of 1,381,069 as of July 1, 2014, San Diego is the eighth-largest city in the United States and second-largest in California. San Diego is the birthplace of California and is known for its mild year-round climate, natural deep-water harbor, extensive beaches, long association with the U.S. Navy, and recent emergence as a healthcare and biotechnology development center. Historically home to the Kumeyaay people, San Diego was the first site visited by Europeans on what is now the West Coast of the United States. Upon landing in San Diego Bay in 1542, Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo claimed the entire area for Spain, forming the basis for the settlement of Alta California 200 years later. The Presidio and Mission of San Diego, founded in 1769, formed the first European settlement in what is now California. In 1821, San Diego became part of newly independent Mexico, and in 1850, became part of the United States following the Mexican–American War and the admission of California to the union. The city is the seat of San Diego County and is the economic center of the region as well as the San Diego–Tijuana metropolitan area. San Diego's main economic engines are military and defense-related activities, tourism, international trade, and manufacturing. The presence of the University of California, San Diego (UCSD), with the affiliated UCSD Medical Center, has helped make the area a center of research in biotechnology.

enrich_metadata.label: Carpinteria, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Carpinteria /kɑːrpᵻntəˈriːə/ is a small oceanside city located in southeastern Santa Barbara County, California, east of Santa Barbara and northwest of Ventura. The population was 13,040 at the 2010 census. Carpinteria Beach is known for its gentle slope and calm waves in selected sandy areas but also good surfing swells in some of the more rocky areas. Seals and sea lions can be seen in the area December through May at the rookery in the nearby Carpinteria Bluffs, as well as an occasional gray whale. Tidepools contain starfish, sea anemones, crabs, snails, octopuses and sea urchins. A marathon-length round trip north of the rookery along the beach to Stearns Wharf in Santa Barbara is possible, though passable only during low tide. A popular campground is located adjacent to the beach. There is bird watching at Carpinteria Salt Marsh Reserve, established in 1977 and administered by the Natural Reserve System of the University of California. The Waldholme Torrey Pine, largest known Torrey pine tree on earth, is located in downtown Carpinteria. Since 1987, the California Avocado Festival has been held in Carpinteria on the first weekend of October. The Santa Barbara Polo Club, one of the main equestrian polo fields in the country, is located in Carpinteria. The city is also home to Hollandia Produce, an organic produce company with 70 employees.[citation needed] lynda.com, an online software training company ranked as one of the fastest-growing private companies in the U.S. (according to Inc. magazine's 2010 500|5000 company listing) had its headquarters in Carpinteria. The company was purchased by LinkedIn in 2015 for $1.5 billion.

Made famous by the 1980's detective TV show, "Simon and Simon", the iconic bridge is a "must do" as you travel to Coronado Island (another "must do" in San Diego!
Anyone visiting San Diego should go to Coronado for a day. Its a lovely town with lots to do. You can stroll the streets and visit the harbor. Eat, have a drink and enjoy!
We wanted to see the Coronado Hotel so we took the drive over. It was a nice drive over an amazing bridge
Check out the bridge and take a drive to Coronado Island. Take the bridge that's in the movies when they are filmed in San Diego.
This bridge had an amazing view of San Diego City and harbor area and is free to go to Coronado Island that had the historic Hotel Del Coronado , one of the landmarks of the city... read more
This is a wonderful bridge. It lets us get from the mainland to Balboa island without getting our feet wet. I recommend it without hesitation.
A very interesting bridge to look at from afar and from up close. The views from it as you drive are great, you get different views in each direction. Be sure to drive across it... read more
On this visit, we did not cross the bridge. Previously, we have gone across this long bridge to Coronado.
If your by Seaport Village you can grab a view from the distance of the Coronado Bridge! It's spectacular when the waves are at high tide. Great photos can be taken from the USS... read more
Cool Long Bridge with views of Coronado Island. I would not really classify this as an attraction, but more of a means to access the wonderful Coronado Island.
Only way to get to Coronado. Not as high as some of the bridges we drove up in Florida. Would be fun to go on a sunny day, but we were there on a rainy day.
Wow this is an incredible bridge. HUGE......and fun to drive over. You see a great view of downtown from on top. Well at least the passagers do. Drivers concentrate on driving.

enrich_metadata.abstract: Buellton is a small city in Santa Barbara County, California, United States. The city of Buellton is one of the communities that make up the Santa Ynez Valley. The population was 4,828 at the 2010 census.
